awd_titl_txt: Understanding Photochemistry and Export of Ozone and Its Precursors from China
awd_abstract_narration:
This project includes measurements and modeling to improve understanding of the key processes and atmospheric emissions that result in regional ozone formation in the North China Plain (NCP), and the transport of pollution out of China with resulting implications for air quality in the United States.  The project includes a collaboration with Chinese scientists and with a German aircraft campaign (EMeRGe-Asia) that will track pollution outflow from the region.

US Scientists will participate in the Ozone Photochemistry and Export from China Experiment (OPECE), that includes in-situ observations at Tuoji Island downwind from the polluted North China Plain (NCP) region. Measurements at Mount Tai in the NCP and at an urban site in Shanghai will be made by collaborators in China. The specific research objectives of the project are as follows: (1) Extend the EMeRGe-Asia aircraft dataset with in-situ observations in the outflow pathway at Tuoji Island, on Mount Tai, and at an urban site in Shanghai. Assess the 3-D modeling capability using in-situ and satellite observations; (2) Examine radical and ozone photochemistry in China using CAREBEIJNG 2014 (Wangdu), OPECE, and EMeRGe-Asia observations; (3) Improve the emission inventories of NOx, aromatics, and other VOCs, and quantify the effects of key photochemical processes and precursor emissions on regional ozone formation and export; and (4) Understand the export processes in the boundary layer and free troposphere during spring and investigate large-scale atmospheric systems affecting springtime pollution export from China.

por.por_cntn:
The Ozone Photochemistry and Export from China Experiment (OPECE) was initiated to investigate air pollution problems in China, a region with severe pollution issues due to rapid industrialization. The project aimed to understand the atmospheric chemistry, pollutant transport, and environmental impacts associated with emissions from China through a combination of field observations, satellite data analysis, and advanced modeling.

 

Successful Execution of Field Campaign: The OPECE team conducted a comprehensive field campaign in Dongying, China, deploying a range of instruments to measure pollutants, aerosols, and atmospheric parameters. This endeavor provided valuable datasets for analyzing atmospheric chemistry and pollutant behavior in the region.

 

Enhanced Understanding of Atmospheric Chemistry and Air Pollution. Selected highlights include: (1) oxygenated volatile organic compound (OVOC) photolysis generates free radicals, accelerating ozone production, especially in regions with high NOx (NO+NO2) and volatile organic compound (VOC) concentrations, with important implications for ozone control strategies. (2) Investigation of HONO production mechanisms reveals implications for ozone sensitivity to NOx changes and regional ozone production variability in polluted regions such as eastern China. (3) Despite decreased NOx emissions, nighttime nitrate radical production shows no increase in China, with implications for nocturnal aerosol formation and climate effects. (4) Factors like heat waves, land cover change, and urbanization significantly contribute to extreme ozone episodes in the North China Plain, with implications for future ozone pollution control strategies under global warming. (5) Discrepancies in Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) models' representation of boundary layer height over China underscore the importance of accurately simulating meteorological parameters and surface energy for predicting future changes in air pollutants. (6) Assessment of satellite NO2 and HCHO data using ground-based measurements highlights discrepancies and emphasizes the importance of accurate observations for studying atmospheric photochemistry. (7) In-source formation (ISF) emerges as a significant source of micron-sized sulfate particles in China, challenging classical formation mechanisms and emphasizing the importance of considering aerosol size distribution in pollution assessment. (8) Modeling analysis reveals an asymmetric response of particulate pH and mass to ammonia emissions, suggesting an initial cost barrier of millions of dollars for controlling wintertime PM2.5 through ammonia emission reduction.

 

Policy Implications: The research findings from OPECE have direct implications for air quality management and policy development in China and beyond. Insights into emission control strategies, ozone and particulate matter trends, and pollutant transport can inform policymakers in designing effective measures to mitigate air pollution and protect public health.
